image.altText: Former premier Mike Ahern

items.synopsis: Former Queensland premier Mike Ahern has died at the age of 81, it has been confirmed today.

title.children: 'A good and decent man': Former Queensland premier Mike Ahern dead at 81

image.altText: A man and a woman smile as they hold an infant.

items.synopsis: Matthew Cox has been charged with murder after police found the bodies of his wife and baby girl.

title.children: Parents of Queensland man accused of killing his wife and 11-week-old daughter in 'state of shock'

image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: Cafes and restaurants saw a boom of big-spending customers after the pandemic. Now, as cost-of-living pressures bite households and the cost of doing business grows, some in the hospitality industry are struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: Only fences or retaining walls stand among the blocks of charred rubble.

items.synopsis: The death toll from a fire disaster on the Hawaiian island of Maui could surge "significantly" higher than 60, the state's governor says.

title.children: Hawaiian fire death toll jumps to 53, thousands homeless in Maui town of Lahaina

image.altText: A small brown and white dog standing on a rocky foreshore, with water visible in the background

items.synopsis: Pet owners are urged to take precautions against wild dog attacks in the Whitsunday region, as one family still grieves the loss of their beloved Cavalier King Charles Spaniel-cross and calls for more to be done.

title.children: Family's heartbreak over wild dog attack as concerns grow over increasing pest population

image.altText: Pauline Hanson, dressed in a red jacket, wears a serious expression as she walks out of the Senate.

items.synopsis: A misleading viral video shared by One Nation leader Pauline Hanson and anti-Voice campaigners has sparked a wave of racial abuse towards an Aboriginal family and has left another couple feeling "crucified".

title.children: Families racially abused, 'crucified' online after misleading anti-Voice video shared by One Nation leader goes viral

image.altText: Dale Josiah sits on a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Dale Josiah and his family moved eight hours' drive from their community for vital health treatment. He's "overwhelmed" a new facility could see the family return home for good.

title.children: Dialysis keeps Dale alive, but his community makes life worth living. Soon, he could have both

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe has faced the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time. Meanwhile, US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: RBA boss says it's 'too early to declare victory' against inflation but 'the worst is over'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're nearing the end of the hearing and Philip Lowe has started to discuss his "popularity" (or lack thereof) depending on what's happening with the interest rate cycle. "We've raised interest rates in election campaigns, we've raised interest rates when it hasn't been popular with the political class," he said. "I hope that people understand that the decisions are taken completely independently. I've been involved in the interest rate setting process for a number of decades, and no politician has indirectly or directly put pressure on the bank during that period. "It's one of the very positive things about Australia — is that the political class do not put pressure on the central bank. And we take our decisions completely independently of the political noise. " I know what we do often is unpopular, and sometimes what I say is unpopular, but that hasn't diminished our resolve to do the right thing. "I hope Australians understand that." He continued discussing how being unpopular often comes with the territory of working at the RBA: "The reason that monetary policy has really been assigned to an independent central bank is it's very difficult for the political class to do what we're currently doing, that is putting up interest rates [and having] people hurting. "It's very uncomfortable, and we're putting up interest rates — that is incredibly unpopular. " I often read in the paper that I'm the most unpopular person in the country. That's fine. "That's why setting of interest rates and managing the inflation cycle has been assigned to an independent central bank, who doesn't have to worry about being liked and being popular. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe acknowledges what he says can be 'unpopular'

children.content: We're nearing the end of the hearing and Philip Lowe has started to discuss his "popularity" (or lack thereof) depending on what's happening with the interest rate cycle.
"We've raised interest rates in election campaigns, we've raised interest rates when it hasn't been popular with the political class," he said.

"I hope that people understand that the decisions are taken completely independently. I've been involved in the interest rate setting process for a number of decades, and no politician has indirectly or directly put pressure on the bank during that period.
"It's one of the very positive things about Australia — is that the political class do not put pressure on the central bank. And we take our decisions completely independently of the political noise.
I know what we do often is unpopular, and sometimes what I say is unpopular, but that hasn't diminished our resolve to do the right thing
"I hope Australians understand that."
He continued discussing how being unpopular often comes with the territory of working at the RBA:

"The reason that monetary policy has really been assigned to an independent central bank is it's very difficult for the political class to do what we're currently doing, that is putting up interest rates [and having] people hurting.
"It's very uncomfortable, and we're putting up interest rates — that is incredibly unpopular.
I often read in the paper that I'm the most unpopular person in the country. That's fine.
"That's why setting of interest rates and managing the inflation cycle has been assigned to an independent central bank, who doesn't have to worry about being liked and being popular. "

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe was also asked if he plans on being a "Tony Abbott" or "Julia Gillard" when it comes to his public presence after leaving the RBA next month. "I don't think I'll be like either," he replied. "My main objective is see if I get my golf handicap in the single digits. "I don't plan to be a public commentator whose job is being a commentator."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe's post-RBA plans? The golf course, not professional commentator

children.content: Philip Lowe was also asked if he plans on being a "Tony Abbott" or "Julia Gillard" when it comes to his public presence after leaving the RBA next month.
"I don't think I'll be like either," he replied.
"My main objective is see if I get my golf handicap in the single digits.
"I don't plan to be a public commentator whose job is being a commentator."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe was asked if he had any regrets during his time as RBA governor. Here's his full response to the question: "I wish I had understood the implications of the pandemic a bit more. The period in early 2020 was incredibly scary, nd our mindset was to provide maximum support medical insurance to protect against the worst possible outcome, and we did that. "It turned out we provided too much support and perhaps too much insurance and that's contributed to inflation problems now. "We didn't fully understand the nature of the pandemic and how long it would last and what the implications would be for the economy. "So I wish in retrospect that we'd been able to understand that in more detail, and if we would have, if we had a better understanding, then we would have responded differently. "I remember being too being told that the unemployment rate was going to 15%, the vaccine wouldn't be for five years, maybe it wasn't effective, people could be forced to stay at home for years — it was incredibly scary and we responded with maximum insurance. "It turned out the scientists did a much better job than anyone thought. We recovered quickly, we all got vaccinated, the vaccine worked and we back to pre-pandemic days. "I wish I understood that and we would have had a different policy response. So that's my biggest regret, that I didn't understand that better."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I wish I had understood the implications of the pandemic,' Lowe says

children.content: Philip Lowe was asked if he had
any regrets
during his time as RBA governor.
Here's his full response to the question:

"I wish I had understood the implications of the pandemic a bit more. The period in early 2020 was incredibly scary, nd our mindset was to provide maximum support medical insurance to protect against the worst possible outcome, and we did that.
"It turned out
we provided too much support and perhaps too much insurance and that's contributed to inflation problems now
"We didn't fully understand the nature of the pandemic and how long it would last and
what the implications would be for the economy
"So I wish in retrospect that we'd been able to understand that in more detail, and if we would have, if we had a better understanding, then we would have responded differently.

"I remember being too being told that the unemployment rate was going to 15%, the vaccine wouldn't be for five years, maybe it wasn't effective, people could be forced to stay at home for years — it was incredibly scary and
we responded with maximum insurance
"It turned out the scientists did a much better job than anyone thought. We recovered quickly, we all got vaccinated, the vaccine worked and we back to pre-pandemic days.
"I wish I understood that and we would have had a different policy response. So that's my biggest regret, that I didn't understand that better."

image.altText: A family carrying luggage walks out the doors of an airport terminal

items.synopsis: The federal government will raise the number of places in Australia's humanitarian visa program to 20,000 from its previous cap of 17,875. The move returns the cap to the level set by Labor when it was last in power.

title.children: Government lifts humanitarian intake cap to 20,000 visas

image.altText: Grace Corvo looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Grace makes and delivers homemade lasagne to supplement her main source of income. She's just one of nearly 200,000 young Australians working more than one job to make ends meet.

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: A husband and wife clutching a letter outside a home.

items.synopsis: Brisbane City Council says it's sorry for sending cryptic letters that led home owners to mistakenly believe their houses would be bulldozed to make way for parks.

title.children: Brisbane council apologises after 'ambiguous' letters leave home owners fearing they will be forced to sell

image.altText: A Spanish player dribbles the ball while being defended against by a Dutch opponent at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Spain scores from the spot to claim a 1-0 lead late in its clash with Netherlands. Later, heavyweights Japan and Sweden meet at Eden Park in Auckland. Follow live.

title.children: Spain takes lead against Netherlands in FIFA World Cup quarterfinal in Wellington

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Maria Caldentey smacks it in off the post. The staggered, slow run up, then not sure how intentional it was, but the shot was RIGHT into the corner, just sneaking in off the woodwork. Clear penalty, and a deserved goal for Spain on the balance of play.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 81' GOAAAAAAAAAAAL SPAIN! From the penalty spot

children.content: (Getty)
Maria Caldentey smacks it in off the post.
The staggered, slow run up, then not sure how intentional it was, but the shot was RIGHT into the corner, just sneaking in off the woodwork.
Clear penalty, and a deserved goal for Spain on the balance of play.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Even scoreline, but not an even half. The Spanish were well and truly on top, and had the ball in the net on one occasion, only for it to be ruled offside. 61% possession for Spain, 12 shots to 1, 23 touches in the opposition box to 3 - the stats speak for themselves. Netherland goalkeeper Daphne van Domselaar has been brilliant. The good news for the Dutch, it's 0-0. They have been dominated, but have not looked completely overwhelmed. A chance to regroup and see what they can offer in the second half. One thing I'd like to see a bit more from Spain is Bonmati in attacking positions. She's been running the game from deep as usual, but we also know she's very dangerous in the box.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Spain 0 - 0 Netherlands

children.content: Even scoreline, but not an even half. The Spanish were well and truly on top, and had the ball in the net on one occasion, only for it to be ruled offside.
(Getty)
61% possession for Spain, 12 shots to 1, 23 touches in the opposition box to 3 - the stats speak for themselves.
Netherland goalkeeper Daphne van Domselaar has been brilliant.
The good news for the Dutch, it's 0-0. They have been dominated, but have not looked completely overwhelmed. A chance to regroup and see what they can offer in the second half.
One thing I'd like to see a bit more from Spain is Bonmati in attacking positions. She's been running the game from deep as usual, but we also know she's very dangerous in the box.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Spain vs Netherlands quarterfinal is underway!

children.content: Tiki-taka or Clockwork Orange?

image.altText: Debbie Kilroy stands at the door of an office.

items.synopsis: Crusading lawyer Debbie Kilroy from Sisters Inside says it's "horrific" a woman on bail had to ask a Queensland court to send her back to jail, after she couldn't find suitable housing.

title.children: Prison 'the only place that can't say no' for women on bail without a home, advocate says

image.altText: Jacinta Price is on the left speaking in the red Senate chamber. On the right is Anthony Albanese speaking in the green house

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians Jacinta Price have been arguing about the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Who is correct?

title.children: CheckMate: Anthony Albanese says the Uluru Statement is one page, Jacinta Price says it's 26. Who is correct?

image.altText: An island-like complex with red buildings and trees surrounded by water is seen from above, a white strip connecting to land

items.synopsis: The city of Bangkok is sinking, with coastal residents rebuilding their homes on stilts and erecting giant walls to protect sacred buildings from being swallowed by the sea.

title.children: 'This not fortune-telling, this is science': Climate change experts sound the alarm on the sinking city of Bangkok

image.altText: Margot winks as the camera as she claps in the air while wearing a gold glittery jumpsuit.

items.synopsis: Kuwait bans the blockbuster film, with Lebanon poised to do the same, saying the film contradicts religious values.

title.children: Barbie faces bans in the Middle East for 'promoting homosexuality'

image.altText: A pallet with documents

items.synopsis: The Australian Electoral Commission has begun printing 13 million pamphlets containing the Yes and No cases for the upcoming referendum on the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Pamphlets detailing Yes and No arguments for the Voice to Parliament being printed

image.altText: Little girl wear coat with fur jacket and holds up wad of cash

items.synopsis: The viral internet star reportedly reaches out to US media, a day after a post on her official Instagram account claimed she and her brother had died.  This is what we know so far about the mystery.

title.children: Child Star Lil Tay is reportedly alive, a day after her instagram claimed she had died

image.altText: A soccer team wearing yellow and green uniforms stand in two rows for a photo before a match

items.synopsis: A Queensland program believed to be one of the oldest female football academies in the world may well be the secret to the Australian team's success.

title.children: 'Something in the water': Why almost half of the Matildas are from Queensland

image.altText: A crocodile basks in a patch of sun on a creek bed.

items.synopsis: The soldiers suffered broken bones and other injuries when they were attacked while swimming in a Queensland waterway in 2021.

title.children: Defence charged over crocodile attack on two soldiers

image.altText: People dressed in gum boots pull at red carpet in a flooded room

items.synopsis: Two of Australia's biggest insurers warn premiums are likely to rise by another 10 per cent in the coming year, with a surge in natural disasters and rising repair and replacement costs to blame.

title.children: Insurers are set to raise premiums another 10pc this year and severe weather is chiefly to blame

image.altText: stadium

items.synopsis: The Pacific Games are coming to Solomon Islands. But with hospitals, roads, and other basic infrastructure in a state of disrepair, many are asking a simple question: Is it a good investment?

title.children: China's built a new stadium for the Pacific's 'mini Olympics'. But not everyone wants it

image.altText: The ship HMAS Brisbane docked at a fleet base in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Visiting warships from India, Japan and the United States will be welcomed into Sydney Harbour on Friday as the annual "Exercise Malabar" military drills are hosted by Australia for the first time.

title.children: Joint naval drills between US, Australia, India and Japan 'more important than ever'

image.altText: A group of people standing outside holding signs in protest

items.synopsis: Angry farmers gather at an event in Tamworth where the prime minister has announced extra drought funding, demanding to have their voices heard on the way renewable energy projects are managed.

title.children: Protesters opposed to renewables rally outside Bush Summit attended by Prime Minister

image.altText: A black and white bird on the left, and a white bird with brown wings and blue touches on the right

items.synopsis: It's time to vote again as our quest to find Australia's favourite animal sound reaches a crescendo. Is your favourite among the top 10, and will it win the race for the nation's hearts and ears?

title.children: The nation has chosen its top 10 animal sounds. Vote now to keep your favourite in the race

image.altText: Melissa Parke.

items.synopsis: As the film Oppenheimer and war in Ukraine both draw the world's attention to the threat of nuclear weapons, Melissa Parke says there is no better time for change.

title.children: New director of campaign to ban nuclear weapons says world has avoided full-scale war through 'dumb luck'

image.altText: A scuba diver examines bleached and dying corals under the water.

items.synopsis: Scientists are concerned that "extremely warm" ocean temperatures on the Great Barrier Reef are a sign of a "potentially catastrophic" coral bleaching event to come.

title.children: Marine heatwave in Great Barrier Reef sparks fear of 'potentially catastrophic' coral bleaching event

image.altText: Journalist Cheng Lei is seen smiling while seated with the Shanghai waterfront in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei, who was arrested and jailed in China three years ago, has released her first public statement describing the harsh conditions of her imprisonment and how much she misses Australia.

title.children: Ten hours of sunlight per year: Australian Cheng Lei's first message from Chinese prison

image.altText: Three people sit around a desk in discussion, in a room with official-looking posters on the wall behind them.

items.synopsis: Federal and territory governments have been warned that a shortfall in interpreters is affecting access to justice for Aboriginal people. Yet the problem's only getting worse.

title.children: This lawyer's client could end up in prison — because he doesn't speak English

image.altText: Rescue workers take part in a rescue operation at a town submerged by typhoon Khanun in Daegu.

items.synopsis: After battering Japan and South Korea, Tropical Storm Khanun is heading towards North Korea, where citizens are told they must prioritise safeguarding propaganda portraits of their leaders, the country's official newspaper says.

title.children: North Koreans ordered to protect Kim dynasty portraits as Tropical Storm Khanun batters East Asia

image.altText: A Pacific Islander worker picking raspberries.

items.synopsis: Changes to the Pacific Islander labour scheme mean workers must be guaranteed a minimum of 30 hours of work each week, but the horticulture industry says the seasonal nature of the work and weather events make that unworkable.

title.children: Growers warn 'unworkable' Pacific Islander worker changes lack critical flexibility required for horticulture

image.altText: A woman wearing a grey jacket and white hat holds a trophy and yells

items.synopsis: The only coach to win back-to-back Women's World Cup titles, former USA boss Jill Ellis, says the Matildas can go all the way.

title.children: Can the Matildas win the World Cup? We asked someone who won it twice
